title: How to Make Gluten Free Ginger Crunch

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 320 degrees Fahrenheit (160°C) — gluten free baking holds up better if done at a lower temperature.
steps.description: As you preheat your oven, spray an 8" (20 centimeter) square baking pan with nonstick cooking spray.

steps.headline: Place the butter and the sugar in a mixing bowl.
Use a stand mixer with a flat paddle attachment or a handheld mixer to cream the butter and sugar together.
Sift the rice flour, baking powder and ginger together by pouring all of the ingredients into a sieve.
steps.description: Tap the sieve and let the ingredients sift through into a bowl.

steps.headline: Mix 1/3 of the sifted dry ingredients into the creamed butter and sugar mixture.
When the dry ingredients are completely blended in, add another third of the dry ingredients.
Add the final third of the dry ingredients after the second addition has blended into the butter and sugar.
Spoon the dough out of the mixing bowl and onto a cutting board.
Knead the dough by pressing it flat with your hands, rolling it into a ball, turning it one-quarter turn, and pressing it flat again.
Keep flattening, rolling and turning until the dough is soft and stretchy.
Place the dough into the greased baking pan.
steps.description: Use a flat spatula to level the dough.

steps.headline: Bake the dough for 20 to 25 minutes or until the dough is golden brown.
steps.description: You can insert a toothpick into the center of the dough to check for doneness. If the toothpick comes out clean, then the dough is cooked through. Link to how to cook use toothpicks for baking article.

steps.headline: Add the butter, confectioner’s sugar, maple syrup and ground ginger to a saucepan and cook over medium heat until the butter has melted.
steps.description: Whisk the mixture vigorously while the butter is melting to make sure that it is well blended.

steps.headline: Pour the glaze over the dough after you’ve removed the baking pan from the oven.
Sprinkle the glaze with chopped walnuts or crystallized ginger if desired.
Allow the dough to cool, and allow the glaze to set.
Cut the bars into 16 portions with a butter knife.
Serve the bars on individual plates along with coffee or hot tea.

text: Preparing the Gluten-Free Dough Preheat your oven to 320 degrees Fahrenheit (160°C) — gluten free baking holds up better if done at a lower temperature. As you preheat your oven, spray an 8" (20 centimeter) square baking pan with nonstick cooking spray. Place the butter and the sugar in a mixing bowl.  Use a stand mixer with a flat paddle attachment or a handheld mixer to cream the butter and sugar together.  Sift the rice flour, baking powder and ginger together by pouring all of the ingredients into a sieve. Tap the sieve and let the ingredients sift through into a bowl. Mix 1/3 of the sifted dry ingredients into the creamed butter and sugar mixture.  When the dry ingredients are completely blended in, add another third of the dry ingredients.  Add the final third of the dry ingredients after the second addition has blended into the butter and sugar.  Spoon the dough out of the mixing bowl and onto a cutting board.  Knead the dough by pressing it flat with your hands, rolling it into a ball, turning it one-quarter turn, and pressing it flat again.  Keep flattening, rolling and turning until the dough is soft and stretchy.  Place the dough into the greased baking pan. Use a flat spatula to level the dough. Bake the dough for 20 to 25 minutes or until the dough is golden brown. You can insert a toothpick into the center of the dough to check for doneness. If the toothpick comes out clean, then the dough is cooked through. Link to how to cook use toothpicks for baking article. Preparing the Icing Add the butter, confectioner’s sugar, maple syrup and ground ginger to a saucepan and cook over medium heat until the butter has melted. Whisk the mixture vigorously while the butter is melting to make sure that it is well blended. Pour the glaze over the dough after you’ve removed the baking pan from the oven.  Sprinkle the glaze with chopped walnuts or crystallized ginger if desired.  Allow the dough to cool, and allow the glaze to set.  Serving the Ginger Crunch Cut the bars into 16 portions with a butter knife.  Serve the bars on individual plates along with coffee or hot tea.
